Award.AwardTitle: The Chemistry and Physics of Titan's Upper Atmosphere Revealed by the Atacama Large Millimeter/submillimeter Array
Award.AbstractNarration:
The atmosphere of Saturn's moon Titan is composed of molecules such as nitrogen and carbon and other elements that were present in the early atmospheres of the rocky planets like Earth. We study Titan's atmosphere to learn more about the early history of the Earth's atmosphere. Cassini spacecraft has mapped simple carbon and nitrogen molecules, revealing many patterns of molecules that change with the changing seasons of Titan. These are, however, only a small number of the types of molecules in Titan's atmosphere, and we do not have coverage of the atmosphere across all of Titan. This is Cassini's last year of operation. Using the new Atacama Large Millimeter/submillimeter Array (ALMA) radio telescope observatory at the same time as Cassini, the astronomers will observe Titan's atmosphere completely using both the radio telescopes and the spacecraft. They will make the first 3-dimensional maps of the types and amounts of molecules in Titan's atmosphere. They will then model the results to learn about how the molecules in the atmosphere are produced, transported, and changed with time. Undergraduate physics and astronomy students from minority-serving schools in the Washington DC area will conduct independent Solar System research with the principal investigator's input and backing at NASA's Goddard Space Flight Center.

Saturn's moon Titan has a thick nitrogen and carbon-rich atmosphere, abundant in complex organic molecules. It is a potential analogue for primitive terrestrial bodies (including the early Earth). Instruments onboard NASA's Cassini spacecraft have provided maps of the smaller hydrocarbons and nitriles, revealing many complex, seasonally-varying molecular abundance patterns. These observations, however, trace only a small subset of Titan's molecular inventory, and have incomplete spatial and temporal coverage. Understanding the formation and evolution of Titan's atmospheric gases is a key step in determining the molecular inventories present in other primitive planetary atmospheres. The Atacama Large Millimeter/submillimeter Array (ALMA) is a revolutionary tool for the detection and instantaneous daylight-hemisphere mapping of Titan's gases. ALMA will be used concurrently with Cassini during its final year of operation to provide complete views of Titan's atmosphere. This research will produce the first instantaneous, spatially-resolved 3-dimensional molecular abundance maps for multiple molecular species on Titan, allowing new and rigorous tests for understanding the basic physics and chemistry of planetary atmospheres. Interpretation of these maps will help generate more detailed chemical models to provide insight into the global production, transport and evolution of molecular material, particularly in Titan's less well-studied middle and upper atmospheres. Isotope abundance ratios will help constrain chemical pathways and trace the origin and evolution of Titan's hydrogen and nitrogen. The principal investigator will mentor undergraduate physics and astronomy students from minority-serving institutions in the Washington DC area, who will conduct independent Solar System research at NASA's Goddard Space Flight Center.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Titan is Saturn's largest moon, noteworthy for its thick atmosphere, which is similar in some ways to Earth's, but much colder, and lacking in oxygen. It may be a good example of primitive, carbon and nitrogen-rich atmospheres to be found on planets elsewhere in our Galaxy, and therefore provides us with a template for learning about the physical and chemical processes that can occur in such environments. Life has not been detected on Titan so far, but a wealth of complex, organic molecules are known to be present, which might contribute towards the ingredients required to get life started. Studying Titan's molecular inventory, and how it changes with time, is therefore an important step in our quest to understand how and where life may be able to occur in the Galaxy.

 

We investigated the chemical composition, temperature structure and global circulation of Titan's atmosphere using a combination of archival research and new observations using the ground-based ALMA telescope and the Cassini spacecraft. Highlights of this research include the first spectroscopic detections of three new molecules on Titan: vinyl cyanide, cyclopropenylidene and methylcyanoacetylene. The detection of vinyl cyanide, in particular, provided new insights into the possibilities for life in cold, non-aqueous planetary environments (see our video "A Titan Discovery" - https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=GiYIRzeL5z0).

 

We also published the highest-resolution maps to-date of short-lived, nitrogen-bearing organic molecules in Titan's atmosphere (see Figure 1). This pioneering work revealed unique snapshot images of the global distributions of Titan's gases, and demonstrated the ALMA telescope's unique capability for continuing Cassini's legacy of detailed atmospheric studies at Titan. Further, time-resolved ALMA observations showed how these gas distributions change with time, and revealed an unexpected, 47% drop in Titan's high-altitude wind speeds over 9 Earth months (a very short period compared with Titan's 29 year seasonal cycle). Such a rapid change indicates strong intermittency of the mysterious mechanism responsible for driving the fast (up to 800 mph) winds that encircle Titan's globe.

 

In terms of broader impacts, Dr. Cordiner worked as a mentor to four undergraduate interns (including two from underrepresented communities in physical science), who were trained in cutting-edge scientific research methods. This included the use of state-of-the-art astronomical tools, programming languages and data analysis techniques, as well as mentoring in advanced communication, presentation and scientific writing skills. These interns were also involved as co-authors of several peer-reviewed journal articles, providing crucial preparation for future careers in STEM fields.
